htmlEmbed:
Privacy Principles3/5/2022

Privacy is an essential part of the Web ([ETHICAL-WEB]). This document provides definitionsfor privacy and related concepts that are applicable worldwide. It also provides a set of privacyprinciples that should guide the development of the Web as a trustworthy platform. People usingthe Web would benefit from a stronger relationship between technology and policy, and thisdocument is written to work with both.

Read

<title>Privacy Principles</title>
  
  
<style>

    .principle {
      border: .5em;
      border-color: cornflowerblue;
      border-style: none none none double;
      background: transparent;
      padding: .5em;
      page-break-inside: avoid;
      margin: 1em auto;
    }
    .principle > .marker {
      color: cornflowerblue;
      font-weight: bold;
    }
    q {
      font-style: italic;
    }
  
</style>

<meta name="description" content="Privacy is an essential part of the Web ([ETHICAL-WEB]). This document provides definitions

principles that should guide the development of the Web as a trustworthy platform. People using
the Web would benefit from a stronger relationship between technology and policy, and this
document is written to work with both.">

    <hr title="Separator for header">
  </div><section id="abstract" class="introductory"><h2>Abstract</h2>

<p>Privacy is an essential part of the Web ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-ethical-web" title="W3C TAG Ethical Web Principles">ETHICAL-WEB</a></cite>]). This document provides definitions
for privacy and related concepts that are applicable worldwide. It also provides a set of privacy
principles that should guide the development of the Web as a trustworthy platform. People using
the Web would benefit from a stronger relationship between technology and policy, and this
document is written to work with both.</p>
</section>

<section class="introductory" id="how-this-document-fits-in"><div class="header-wrapper"><h2 id="how-this-document-fits-in-0">How This Document Fits In</h2><a class="self-link" href="#how-this-document-fits-in" aria-label="Permalink for this Section"></a></div>


<p>This document elaborates on the <a href="https://www.w3.org/2001/tag/doc/ethical-web-principles/#privacy">privacy principle</a> in the <cite><a data-matched-text="[[[Ethical-Web]]]" href="https://www.w3.org/2001/tag/doc/ethical-web-principles/">W3C TAG Ethical Web Principles</a></cite>. It doesn't
address how to balance the different principles in that document if they come into
conflict.</p>
<p>Privacy is covered by legal frameworks and this document recognises that existing data
protection laws take precedence for legal matters. However, because the Web is global, we
benefit from having shared concepts to guide its evolution as a system built for the people using it
([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-rfc8890" title="The Internet is for End Users">RFC8890</a></cite>]). A clear and well-defined view of privacy on the Web, informed by research,
can hopefully help all the Web's participants in different legal regimes. Our shared
understanding is that the law is a floor, not a ceiling.</p>
</section>

<section id="an-introduction-to-privacy-on-the-web"><div class="header-wrapper"><h2 id="intro"><bdi class="secno">1. </bdi>An Introduction to Privacy on the Web</h2><a class="self-link" href="#intro" aria-label="Permalink for Section 1."></a></div><p>The Web is for everyone ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-for-everyone" title="This Is For Everyone">For-Everyone</a></cite>]). It is "<i>a platform that helps people and provides a
net positive social benefit</i>" ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-ethical-web" title="W3C TAG Ethical Web Principles">ETHICAL-WEB</a></cite>], [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-design-principles" title="Web Platform Design Principles">design-principles</a></cite>]). One of the ways in which the
Web serves people is by protecting them in the face of asymmetries of power, and this includes
establishing and enforcing rules to govern the power of data.</p>
<p>The Web is a social and technical system made up of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-information" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-information-1">information flows</a>. Because this document
is specifically about <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-privacy" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-privacy-1">privacy</a> as it applies to the Web, it focuses on privacy with respect to
information flows. Our goal is not to cover all privacy issues, but rather to provide enough
background to support the Web community in making informed decisions about privacy and to weave
privacy into the architecture of the Web. Few architectural principles are absolute, and privacy is
no exception: privacy can come into tension with other desirable properties of an ethical
architecture, and when that happens the Web community will have to work together to strike the right
balance.</p>
<p>Information is power. It can be used to predict and to influence people, as well as to design online
spaces that control people's behaviour. The collection and <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-1">processing</a> of information in greater
volume, with greater precision and reliability, with increasing interoperability across a growing
variety of data types, and at intensifying speed is leading to an unprecedented concentration of power
that threatens private and public liberties.</p>
<p>What's more, automation and the increasing computerisation of all aspects of our lives
both increase the power of information and decrease the cost of a number of intrusive
behaviours that would be more easily kept in check if the perpetrator had to be in the same room as
the victim.</p>
<p>These asymmetries of information and of automation create commanding asymmetries of power.</p>
<p><dfn data-lt="governance|Data governance" id="dfn-governance" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">Data governance</dfn> is the system of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-1">principles</a> that regulate <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-information" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-information-2">information flows</a>. When
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-1">people</a> are involved in <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-information" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-information-3">information flows</a>, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-governance" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-governance-1">data governance</a> determines how
these <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-2">principles</a> constrain and distribute the power of information between different <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-actors" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-actors-1">actors</a>.
The <dfn id="dfn-principles" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">principles</dfn> describe the way in which different <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-actors" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-actors-2">actors</a> may, must,
or must not produce or <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-2">process</a> flows of information from, to, or about other <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-actors" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-actors-3">actors</a>
([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-gkc-privacy" title="Governing Privacy in Knowledge Commons">GKC-Privacy</a></cite>], [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-iad" title="Understanding Institutional Diversity">IAD</a></cite>]).</p>
<p>Typically, <dfn data-plurals="actor" id="dfn-actors" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">actors</dfn> are <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-2">people</a> but they can also be collective endeavours such as
companies, associations, or political parties (eg. in the case of espionage), which are known as
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-1">parties</a>. It is important to keep in mind that not all people are equal in how they can resist
the imposition of unfair <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-3">principles</a>: some <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-3">people</a> are more <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-vulnerable" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-vulnerable-1">vulnerable</a> and therefore in greater
need of protection. The focus of this document is on the impact that this power differential can
have against people, but it can also impact other <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-actors" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-actors-4">actors</a>, such as companies or governments.</p>
<p><a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-4">Principles</a> vary from <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-1">context</a> to <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-2">context</a> ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-understanding-privacy" title="Understanding Privacy">Understanding-Privacy</a></cite>], [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-contextual-integrity" title="Privacy As Contextual Integrity">Contextual-Integrity</a></cite>]): people
have different expectations of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-privacy" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-privacy-2">privacy</a> at work, at a café, or at home for instance. Understanding and
evaluating a privacy situation is best done by clearly identifying:</p>
<ul>
<li>Its <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-actors" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-actors-5">actors</a>, which include the subject of the information as well as the sender and the recipient
of the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-information" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-information-4">information flow</a>. (Note that recipients might not always want to be recipients.)</li>
<li>The specific type of data in the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-information" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-information-5">information flow</a>.</li>
<li>The <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-5">principles</a> that are in use in this specific context.</li>
</ul>
<p>It is important to keep in mind that there are <em>always</em> privacy <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-6">principles</a> and that all
of them imply different power dynamics. Some <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-7">principles</a> may be more permissive, but that does
not render them neutral — it merely indicates that they are supportive of the power dynamic that
emerges from permissive <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-3">processing</a>. We must therefore determine which <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-8">principles</a>
best align with ethical Web values in Web <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-3">contexts</a> ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-ethical-web" title="W3C TAG Ethical Web Principles">ETHICAL-WEB</a></cite>], [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-why-privacy" title="Why Privacy Matter">Why-Privacy</a></cite>]).</p>
<p><dfn data-lt="information|Information flows" data-plurals="information flow" id="dfn-information" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">Information flows</dfn> as understood in this document are information
exchanged or processed by <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-actors" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-actors-6">actors</a>. The information itself need not necessarily be
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-1">personal data</a>. Disruptive or interruptive information flowing <em>to</em> a
person is in scope, as is <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-de-identified" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-de-identified-1">de-identified</a> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-2">data</a> that can be used to manipulate people or that
was extracted by observing people's behaviour on someone else's website.</p>
<p><a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-information" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-information-6">Information flows</a> need to be understood from more than one perspective: there is the flow of information
<em>about</em> a person (the subject) being processed or transmitted to any other party, and there is
the flow of information <em>towards</em> a person (the recipient). Recipients can have their privacy violated in multiple ways such as
unexpected shocking images, loud noises while one intends to sleep, manipulative information,
interruptive messages when a person's focus is on something else, or harassment when they seek
social interactions.</p>
<section id="individual-autonomy"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="autonomy"><bdi class="secno">1.1 </bdi>Individual Autonomy</h3><a class="self-link" href="#autonomy" aria-label="Permalink for Section 1.1"></a></div><p>A <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-4">person</a>'s <dfn data-lt="autonomous|autonomy" id="dfn-autonomous" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">autonomy</dfn> is their ability to make decisions of their own volition,
without undue influence from other <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-2">parties</a>. People have limited intellectual resources and
time with which to weigh decisions, and by necessity rely on shortcuts when making
decisions. This makes their preferences, including privacy preferences, malleable and susceptible to
manipulation ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-privacy-behavior" title="Privacy and Human Behavior in the Age of Information">Privacy-Behavior</a></cite>], [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-digital-market-manipulation" title="Digital Market Manipulation">Digital-Market-Manipulation</a></cite>]). A <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-5">person</a>'s <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-autonomous" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-autonomous-1">autonomy</a> is enhanced by a
system or device when that system offers a shortcut that aligns more with what that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-6">person</a> would
have decided given arbitrary amounts of time and relatively unlimited intellectual ability;
and <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-autonomous" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-autonomous-2">autonomy</a> is decreased when a similar shortcut goes against decisions made under such
ideal conditions.</p>
<p>Affordances and interactions that decrease <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-autonomous" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-autonomous-3">autonomy</a> are known as <dfn data-plurals="dark pattern" id="dfn-dark-patterns" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">dark patterns</dfn>.
A <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-dark-patterns" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-dark-patterns-1">dark pattern</a> does not have to be intentional ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-dark-patterns" title="Dark patterns: past, present, and future">Dark-Patterns</a></cite>], [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-dark-pattern-dark" title="What Makes a Dark Pattern… Dark? Design Attributes, Normative Considerations, and Measurement Methods">Dark-Pattern-Dark</a></cite>]).</p>
<p>Because we are all subject to motivated reasoning, the design of defaults and affordances
that may impact <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-autonomous" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-autonomous-4">autonomy</a> should be the subject of independent scrutiny.</p>
<p>Given the large volume of potential <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-3">data</a>-related decisions in today's data economy,
complete informational self-determination is impossible. This fact, however, should not be
confused with the idea that privacy is dead. Careful design of our technological
infrastructure can ensure that people's <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-autonomous" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-autonomous-5">autonomy</a> with respect to their own <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-4">data</a>
is enhanced through <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-appropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-appropriately-1">appropriate</a> defaults and choice architectures.</p>
<section id="opt-in-consent-opt-out-global-controls"><div class="header-wrapper"><h4 id="opt-in-out"><bdi class="secno">1.1.1 </bdi>Opt-in, Consent, Opt-out, Global Controls</h4><a class="self-link" href="#opt-in-out" aria-label="Permalink for Section 1.1.1"></a></div><div class="issue" id="issue-container-generatedID"><div role="heading" class="issue-title marker" id="h-issue" aria-level="2"><span>Issue</span></div><aside class="">

<p>Broaden this from <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-4">processing</a> to general interactions with systems.</p>
</aside></div>

<p>Different procedural mechanisms exist to enable <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-7">people</a> to control how they interact
with systems in the world. Mechanisms that increase the number of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-purpose" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-purpose-1">purposes</a> for which
their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-5">data</a> is being <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-5">processed</a> are referred to as <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-opt-in" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-opt-in-1">opt-in</a> or
<dfn data-lt="opt in|opt-in|consent" id="dfn-opt-in" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">consent</dfn>; mechanisms that decrease this number of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-purpose" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-purpose-2">purposes</a> are known as
<dfn data-lt="opt out|opt-out" id="dfn-opt-out" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">opt-out</dfn>.</p>
<p>When deployed thoughtfully, these mechanisms can enhance <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-8">people</a>'s <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-autonomous" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-autonomous-6">autonomy</a>. Often,
however, they are used as a way to avoid putting in the difficult work of deciding which
types of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-6">processing</a> are <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-appropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-appropriately-2">appropriate</a> and which are not, offloading <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-privacy-labor" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-privacy-labor-1">privacy labour</a>
to the people using a system.</p>
<p>In specific cases, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-9">people</a> should be able to <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-opt-in" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-opt-in-2">consent</a> to more
sensitive <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-purpose" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-purpose-3">purposes</a>, such as having their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-1">identity</a> recognised across contexts or
their reading history shared with a company. The burden of proof on ensuring that informed
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-opt-in" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-opt-in-3">consent</a> has been obtained needs to be very high in this case.
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-opt-in" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-opt-in-4">Consent</a> is comparable to the
general problem of permissions on the Web platform. In the same way that it should be clear when a
given device capability is in use (eg. you are providing geolocation or camera access), sharing
data should be set up in such a way that it requires deliberate, specific action from the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-10">person</a>
(eg. triggering a form control that is not on a modal dialog) and if that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-opt-in" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-opt-in-5">consent</a> is persistent,
there should be a vivid indicator that data is being transmitted shown at all times, in such a way
that the person can easily switch it off. In general, providing <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-opt-in" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-opt-in-6">consent</a> should be rare,
difficult, highly intentional, and temporary.</p>
<p>When an <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-opt-out" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-opt-out-1">opt-out</a> mechanism exists, it should preferably be complemented by a
<dfn id="dfn-global-opt-out" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">global opt-out</dfn> mechanism. The function of a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-global-opt-out" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-global-opt-out-1">global opt-out</a> mechanism is to
rectify the <dfn class="export" data-export="" data-plurals="automation asymmetries" id="dfn-automation-asymmetry" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">automation asymmetry</dfn> whereby service providers can automate
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-7">data processing</a> but <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-11">people</a> have to take manual action to prevent it. A good example of a
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-global-opt-out" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-global-opt-out-2">global opt-out</a> mechanism is the <em>Global Privacy Control</em> [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-gpc" title="Global Privacy Control (GPC)">GPC</a></cite>].</p>
<p>Conceptually, a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-global-opt-out" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-global-opt-out-3">global opt-out</a> mechanism is an automaton operating as part of the
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-1">user agent</a>, which is to say that it is equivalent to a robot that would carry out a
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-12">person</a>'s bidding by pressing an <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-opt-out" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-opt-out-2">opt-out</a> button with every interaction that the
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-13">person</a> has with a site, or more generally conveys an expression of the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-14">person</a>'s
rights in a relevant jurisdiction. (For instance, under [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-gdpr" title="General Data Protection Regulations (GDPR) / Regulation (EU) 2016/679">GDPR</a></cite>], the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-15">person</a> may be
conveying objections to <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-8">processing</a> based on legitimate interest or the withdrawal of
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-opt-in" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-opt-in-7">consent</a> to specific <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-purpose" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-purpose-4">purposes</a>.) It should be noted that, since a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-global-opt-out" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-global-opt-out-4">global opt-out</a>
signal is reaffirmed automatically with every interaction, it will take precedence
in terms of specificity over any general obtention of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-opt-in" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-opt-in-8">consent</a> by a site,
and only superseded by specific <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-opt-in" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-opt-in-9">consent</a> obtained through a deliberate action taken by
the user with the intent of overriding their global opt-out.</p>
</section><section id="privacy-labour-0"><div class="header-wrapper"><h4 id="privacy-labour"><bdi class="secno">1.1.2 </bdi>Privacy Labour</h4><a class="self-link" href="#privacy-labour" aria-label="Permalink for Section 1.1.2"></a></div><p><dfn data-lt="privacy labor|labour|labor|Privacy labour" id="dfn-privacy-labor" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">Privacy labour</dfn> is the practice of having a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-16">person</a> carry out
the work of ensuring <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-9">data processing</a> of which they are the subject or recipient is
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-appropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-appropriately-3">appropriate</a>, instead of having the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-3">parties</a> be responsible for that work.
Data systems that are based on asking <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-17">people</a> for their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-opt-in" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-opt-in-10">consent</a> tend to increase
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-privacy-labor" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-privacy-labor-2">privacy labour</a>.</p>
<p>More generally, implementations of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-privacy" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-privacy-3">privacy</a> are often dominated by self-governing approaches that
offload <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-privacy-labor" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-privacy-labor-3">labour</a> to <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-18">people</a>. This is notably true of the regimes descended from the
<dfn data-lt="FIPs|Fair Information Practices" id="dfn-fips" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">Fair Information Practices</dfn> (<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-fips" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-fips-1">FIPs</a>), a loose set of principles initially
elaborated in the 1970s in support of individual <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-autonomous" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-autonomous-7">autonomy</a> in the face of growing concerns with databases. The
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-fips" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-fips-2">FIPs</a> generally assume that there is sufficiently little <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-10">data processing</a> taking place that any
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-19">person</a> will be able to carry out sufficient diligence to enable <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-autonomous" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-autonomous-8">autonomy</a> in their
decision-making. Since they entirely offload the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-privacy-labor" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-privacy-labor-4">privacy labour</a>
to people and assume perfect, unlimited <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-autonomous" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-autonomous-9">autonomy</a>, the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-fips" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-fips-3">FIPs</a> do not forbid specific
types of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-11">data processing</a> but only place them under different procedural requirements.
Such an approach is <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-appropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-appropriately-4">appropriate</a> for <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-4">parties</a> that are processing data in the 1970s.</p>
<p>One notable issue with procedural, self-governing approaches to privacy is that they tend to have the same
requirements in situations where people find themselves in a significant asymmetry of
power with a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-5">party</a> — for instance a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-20">person</a> using an essential service provided by a
monopolistic platform — and those where people and <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-6">parties</a> are very much on equal
footing, or even where the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-21">person</a> may have greater power, as is the case with small
businesses operating in a competitive environment. It further does not consider cases in
which one <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-7">party</a> may coerce other <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-8">parties</a> into facilitating its <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-inappropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-inappropriately-1">inappropriate</a>
practices, as is often the case with dominant players in advertising or
in content aggregation ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-consent-lackeys" title="Publishers tell Google: We're not your consent lackeys">Consent-Lackeys</a></cite>], [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-cat" title="Content Aggregation Technology (CAT)">CAT</a></cite>]).</p>
<p>Reference to the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-fips" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-fips-4">FIPs</a> survives to this day. They are often referenced as "<i>transparency
and choice</i>", which, in today's digital environment, is often an indication that
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-inappropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-inappropriately-2">inappropriate</a> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-12">processing</a> is being described.</p>
</section></section><section id="collective-governance"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="collective"><bdi class="secno">1.2 </bdi>Collective Governance</h3><a class="self-link" href="#collective" aria-label="Permalink for Section 1.2"></a></div><p>Privacy <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-9">principles</a> are socially negotiated and the definition of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-privacy" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-privacy-4">privacy</a> is essentially
contested ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-privacy-contested" title="Privacy is an essentially contested concept: a multi-dimensional analytic for mapping privacy">Privacy-Contested</a></cite>]). This makes privacy a problem of collective action ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-gkc-privacy" title="Governing Privacy in Knowledge Commons">GKC-Privacy</a></cite>]).
Group-level <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-13">data processing</a> may impact populations or individuals, including in
ways that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-22">people</a> could not control even under the optimistic assumptions of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-opt-in" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-opt-in-11">consent</a>.
For example, based on group-level analysis, a company may know that <var>site.example</var>
is predominantly visited by <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-23">people</a> of a given race or gender, and decide not to run its
job ads there. Visitors to that page are implicitly having their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-6">data</a> processed in
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-inappropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-inappropriately-3">inappropriate</a> ways, with no way to discover the discrimination or seek relief
([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-relational-governance" title="A Relational Theory of Data Governance">Relational-Governance</a></cite>]).</p>
<p>What we consider is therefore not just the relation between the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-24">people</a> who share data
and the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-9">parties</a> that invite that disclosure ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-relational-turn" title="A Relational Turn for Data Protection?">Relational-Turn</a></cite>]), but also between the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-25">people</a>
who may find themselves categorised indirectly as part of a group even without sharing data. One key
understanding here is that such relations may persist even when data is <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-de-identified" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-de-identified-2">de-identified</a>. What's
more, such categorisation of people, voluntary or not, changes the way in which the world operates.
This can produce self-reinforcing loops that can damage both individuals and
groups ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-seeing-like-a-state" title="Seeing Like a State: How Certain Schemes to Improve the Human Condition Have Failed">Seeing-Like-A-State</a></cite>]).</p>
<p>In general, collective issues in <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-7">data</a> require collective solutions. Web standards help with
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-governance" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-governance-2">data governance</a> by defining structural controls
in <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-2">user agents</a> and establishing or delegating to institutions that can handle issues of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-privacy" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-privacy-5">privacy</a>.
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-governance" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-governance-3">Governance</a> will often struggle to achieve its goals if it works primarily by
increasing <em>individual</em> control instead of acting collectively.</p>
<p>Collecting data at large scales can have significant pro-social outcomes. Problems tend to
emerge when <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-actors" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-actors-7">actors</a> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-14">process</a> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-8">data</a>
for collective benefit and for <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-self-dealing" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-self-dealing-1">self-dealing</a> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-purpose" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-purpose-5">purposes</a> at the same time.
The <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-self-dealing" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-self-dealing-2">self-dealing</a> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-purpose" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-purpose-6">purposes</a> are often justified as bankrolling the pro-social outcomes
but this requires collective oversight to be <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-appropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-appropriately-5">appropriate</a>.</p>
<section id="group-privacy-0"><div class="header-wrapper"><h4 id="group-privacy"><bdi class="secno">1.2.1 </bdi>Group Privacy</h4><a class="self-link" href="#group-privacy" aria-label="Permalink for Section 1.2.1"></a></div><p>There are different ways for <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-26">people</a> to become members of a group. Either they can join it
deliberately, making it a self-constituted group such as when joining a club, or they can be
classified into it by an external party, typically a bureaucracy or its computerised equivalent
([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-beyond-individual" title="Privacy Beyond the Individual Level (in Modern Socio-Technical Perspectives on Privacy)">Beyond-Individual</a></cite>]). In the latter case, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-27">people</a> may not be aware that they are being
grouped together, and the definition of the group may not be intelligible (for instance if it is
created from opaque machine learning techniques).</p>
<p>Protecting group privacy can take place at two different levels. The existence of a group or at
least its activities may need to be protected even in cases in which its members are guaranteed to
remain anonymous. We refer to this as "group privacy." Conversely, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-28">People</a> may wish to protect
knowledge that they are members of the group even though the existence of the group and its actions
may be well known (eg. membership in a dissidents movement under authoritarian rule), which we call
"membership privacy". An example <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-privacy-violation" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-privacy-violation-1">privacy violation</a> for the former case
is the fitness app Strava that did not reveal individual behaviour or identity but published heat
maps of popular running routes. In doing so, it revealed secret US bases around which military
personnel took frequent runs ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-strava-debacle" title="The Latest Data Privacy Debacle">Strava-Debacle</a></cite>], [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-strava-reveal-military" title="Strava Fitness App Can Reveal Military Sites, Analysts Say">Strava-Reveal-Military</a></cite>]).</p>
<p>When <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-29">people</a> do not know that they are members of a group, when they cannot easily find other
members of the group so as to advocate for their rights together, or when they cannot easily
understand why they are being categorised into a given group, their ability to protect themselves
through self-governing approaches to privacy is largely eliminated.</p>
<p>One common problem in group privacy is when the actions of one member of a group reveals information
that other members would prefer were not shared in this way (or at all). For instance, one person
may publish a picture of an event in which they are featured alongside others while the other people
captured in the same picture would prefer their participation not to be disclosed. Another example
of such issues are sites that enable people to upload their contacts: the person performing the
upload might be more open to disclosing their social networks than the people they are connected to
are. Such issues do not necessarily admit simple, straightforward solutions but they need to be
carefully considered by people building websites.</p>
</section><section id="transparency-and-research"><div class="header-wrapper"><h4 id="transparency"><bdi class="secno">1.2.2 </bdi>Transparency and Research</h4><a class="self-link" href="#transparency" aria-label="Permalink for Section 1.2.2"></a></div><p>While transparency rarely helps enough to inform the individual choices that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-30">people</a> may
make or in increasing their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-autonomous" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-autonomous-10">autonomy</a>, it plays a critical role in letting
researchers and reporters inform our
collective decision-making about privacy <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-10">principles</a>. This consideration extends the
TAG's resolution on a <a href="https://www.w3.org/blog/2015/11/strong-web-platform-statement/">Strong and Secure Web Platform</a>
to ensure that "<i>broad testing and audit continues to be possible</i>" where
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-information" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-information-7">information flows</a> and automated decisions are involved.</p>
<p>Such transparency can only function if there are strong <a href="#data-rights">rights</a> of access to data (including data
derived from one's personal data) as well as mechanisms to explain the outcomes of automated
decisions.</p>
</section></section><section id="people-s-agents"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="user-agents"><bdi class="secno">1.3 </bdi>People's Agents</h3><a class="self-link" href="#user-agents" aria-label="Permalink for Section 1.3"></a></div><p>The <dfn data-plurals="user agents" id="dfn-user-agent" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">user agent</dfn> acts as an intermediary between a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-31">person</a> (its <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-32">user</a>) and the web.
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-3">User agents</a> implement, to the extent possible, the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-11">principles</a> that collective governance
establishes in favour of individuals. They seek to prevent the creation of asymmetries of
information, and serve their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-33">user</a> by providing them with automation to rectify
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-automation-asymmetry" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-automation-asymmetry-1">automation asymmetries</a>. Where possible, they protect their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-34">user</a> from receiving
intrusive messages.</p>
<p>The <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-4">user agent</a> is expected to align fully with the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-35">person</a> using it and operate exclusively
in that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-36">person</a>'s interest. It is <em>not</em> the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-first-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-first-parties-1">first party</a>. The <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-5">user agent</a> serves the
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-37">person</a> as a <dfn id="dfn-trustworthy-agent" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">trustworthy agent</dfn>:
it always puts that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-38">person</a>'s interest first. In some occasions, this can mean protecting
that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-39">person</a> from themselves by preventing them from carrying out a dangerous decision,
or by slowing down the person in their decision. For example, the
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-6">user agent</a> will make it difficult for that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-40">person</a> to connect to a site if it can't verify
that the site is authentic. It will check that that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-41">person</a> really intends to expose a
sensitive device to a page. It will prevent that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-42">person</a> from consenting to the permanent
monitoring of their behaviour. Its <dfn class="export" data-export="" id="dfn-user-agent-duties" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">user agent duties</dfn> include
([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-taking-trust-seriously" title="Taking Trust Seriously in Privacy Law">Taking-Trust-Seriously</a></cite>]):</p>
<dl>
  <dt><dfn class="export" data-export="" id="dfn-duty-of-protection" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">Duty of Protection</dfn></dt>
  <dd>
    Protection requires <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-7">user agents</a> to actively protect their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-43">user</a>'s data, beyond
    simple security measures. It is insufficient to just encrypt at rest and in transit,
    but the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-8">user agent</a> must also limit retention, help ensure that only strictly
    necessary data is collected, and require guarantees from any <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-10">party</a> that the user agent can
    reasonably be aware that it is shared to.
  </dd>
  <dt><dfn class="export" data-export="" id="dfn-duty-of-discretion" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">Duty of Discretion</dfn></dt>
  <dd>
    Discretion requires the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-9">user agent</a> to make best efforts to enforce
    <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-12">principles</a> by taking care in the ways it discloses the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-9">personal data</a>
    that it manages. Discretion is not
    confidentiality or secrecy: trust
    can be preserved even when the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-10">user agent</a> shares some <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-10">personal data</a>, so long as
    it is done in an <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-appropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-appropriately-6">appropriately</a> discreet manner.
  </dd>
  <dt><dfn class="export" data-export="" id="dfn-duty-of-honesty" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">Duty of Honesty</dfn></dt>
  <dd>
    Honesty requires that the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-11">user agent</a> try to give its <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-44">user</a>
    information of which the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-12">user agent</a> can reasonably be aware, that is relevant to
    them and that will increase their
    autonomy, as long as they can understand it and there's an appropriate
    time. This is almost never when the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-45">person</a> is trying to do something else such as
    read a page or activate a feature. The duty of honesty goes well beyond that of
    transparency that is often included in older privacy regimes. Unlike transparency, honesty
    can't hide relevant information in complex legal notices and it can't rely on
    very short summaries provided in a consent dialog.
    If the person has provided <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-opt-in" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-opt-in-12">consent</a> to <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-15">processing</a> of their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-11">personal data</a>,
    the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-13">user agent</a> should inform the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-46">person</a> of ongoing <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-16">processing</a>, with a
    level of obviousness that is proportional to the reasonably foreseeable impact of the processing.
  </dd>
  <dt><dfn class="export" data-export="" id="dfn-duty-of-loyalty" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">Duty of Loyalty</dfn></dt>
  <dd>
    Because the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-14">user agent</a> is a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-trustworthy-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-trustworthy-agent-1">trustworthy agent</a>, it is held to be loyal to the
    <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-47">person</a> using it in all situations, including in preference to the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-15">user agent</a>'s implementer.
    When a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-16">user agent</a> carries out <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-17">processing</a> that is not in the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-48">person</a>'s
    interest but instead benefits another <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-actors" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-actors-8">actor</a> (such as the user agent's implementer) that behaviour is
    known as <dfn id="dfn-self-dealing" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">self-dealing</dfn>. Behaviour can be <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-self-dealing" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-self-dealing-3">self-dealing</a> even if it is done at the
    same time as <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-18">processing</a> that is in the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-49">person</a>'s interest, what matters is that it
    potentially conflicts with that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-50">person</a>'s interest. <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-self-dealing" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-self-dealing-4">Self-dealing</a> is always
    <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-inappropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-inappropriately-4">inappropriate</a>. Loyalty is the avoidance of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-self-dealing" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-self-dealing-5">self-dealing</a>.
  </dd>
</dl>

<p>These duties ensure the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-17">user agent</a> will <em>care</em> for its <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-51">user</a>. In academic
research, this relationship with a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-trustworthy-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-trustworthy-agent-2">trustworthy agent</a> is often described as "fiduciary"
[<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-fiduciary-ua" title="The Fiduciary Duties of User Agents">Fiduciary-UA</a></cite>]. Some jurisdictions may have a distinct legal meaning for "fiduciary."</p>
<p>Many of the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-13">principles</a> described in the rest of this document extend the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-18">user agent</a>'s duties and
make them more precise.</p>
</section></section><section id="principles-for-privacy-on-the-web"><div class="header-wrapper"><h2 id="x2-principles-for-privacy-on-the-web"><bdi class="secno">2. </bdi>Principles for Privacy on the Web</h2><a class="self-link" href="#principles-for-privacy-on-the-web" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2."></a></div>
<p>As indicated above, different <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-4">contexts</a> require different <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-14">principles</a>. This section describes a set
of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-15">principles</a> designed to apply to the Web <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-5">context</a> in general. The Web is a big place, and we
fully expect more specific <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-6">contexts</a> of the Web to add their own <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-16">principles</a> to further constrain
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-information" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-information-8">information flows</a>.</p>
<p>To the extent possible, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-19">user agents</a> are expected to enforce these <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-17">principles</a>. However, this is not
always possible and additional enforcement mechanisms are needed. One particularly salient issue
is that a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-7">context</a> is not defined in terms of who owns it (it is not a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-11">party</a>). Sharing
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-12">data</a> between different <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-8">contexts</a> of a single company is just as much a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-privacy-violation" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-privacy-violation-2">privacy violation</a> as
if the same data were shared between unrelated <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-12">parties</a>.</p>
<div class="issue" id="issue-container-generatedID-0"><div role="heading" class="issue-title marker" id="h-issue-0" aria-level="2"><span>Issue</span></div><aside class="">


<p>  Please note that the initial focus of this draft was on <a href="#intro" class="sec-ref"><bdi class="secno">1. </bdi>An Introduction to Privacy on the Web</a>. This section is
  incomplete and has uneven maturity. The absence of a specific principle should not be seen as an
  indication that the Task Force considers it to be of lesser importance.</p>
</aside></div>

<section id="principles-for-identity-on-the-web"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="identity"><bdi class="secno">2.1 </bdi>Principles for Identity on the Web</h3><a class="self-link" href="#identity" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.1"></a></div><div class="issue" id="issue-container-generatedID-1"><div role="heading" class="issue-title marker" id="h-issue-1" aria-level="2"><span>Issue</span></div><aside class="">


<p>  This section has not been edited for narrative.</p>
</aside></div>

<p>A <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-52">person</a>'s <dfn data-plurals="identities" id="dfn-identity" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">identity</dfn> is the set of characteristics that define them. Their identity
<em>in a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-9">context</a></em> is the set of characteristics they present to that context. People
frequently present different identities to different contexts, and also frequently share an identity
among several contexts.</p>
<p><dfn id="dfn-cross-context-recognition" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">Cross-context recognition</dfn> is the act of recognising that an <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-2">identity</a> in one
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-10">context</a> is the same <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-53">person</a> as an <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-3">identity</a> in another <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-11">context</a>. <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-cross-context-recognition" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-cross-context-recognition-1">Cross-context recognition</a> can at times be <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-appropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-appropriately-7">appropriate</a> but anyone who does it needs to be careful not to
apply the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-18">principles</a> of one <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-12">context</a> in ways that violate the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-19">principles</a> around use of information
acquired in a different <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-13">context</a>. (For example, if you meet your therapist at a cocktail party,
you expect them to have rather different discussion topics with you than they usually would, and
possibly even to pretend they do not know you.) This is particularly true for <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-vulnerable" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-vulnerable-2">vulnerable</a> people
as recognising them in different <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-14">contexts</a> may force their vulnerability into the open.</p>
<p>In computer systems and on the Web, an <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-4">identity</a> seen by a particular website is typically
assigned an <dfn data-plurals="identifiers" id="dfn-identifier" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">identifier</dfn> of some type, which makes it easier for an automated system to
store data about that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-54">person</a>. Examples of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identifier" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identifier-1">identifiers</a> for a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-55">person</a> can be:</p>
<ul>
<li>their name,</li>
<li>an identification number including those mapping to a device that this <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-56">person</a> may be using,</li>
<li>their phone number,</li>
<li>their location data,</li>
<li>an online identifier such as email or IP addresses, or</li>
<li>factors specific to their physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural, or social
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-5">identity</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p>Strings derived from <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identifier" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identifier-2">identifiers</a>, for instance through hashing, are still
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identifier" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identifier-3">identifiers</a> so long as they may identify a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-57">person</a>.</p>
<div class="practice principle"><a class="marker self-link" href="#principle-identity-per-context"><bdi lang="en">Principle</bdi></a>: <span class="practicelab" id="principle-identity-per-context">A <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-20">user agent</a> should help
its user present the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-6">identity</a> they want in each <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-15">context</a> they find themself
in.</span>

<p></p>
<p>Sometimes this means the UA should ensure that one site can't learn anything about their
user's behavior on another site, while at other times the UA should help their user prove to
one site that they have a particular identity on another site.</p>
</div>

<p>To do this, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-21">user agents</a> have to make some assumptions about the borders between <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-16">contexts</a>. By
default, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-22">user agents</a> define a <dfn data-plurals="machine-enforceable contexts" id="dfn-machine-enforceable-context" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">machine-enforceable context</dfn> or <dfn data-plurals="partitions" id="dfn-partition" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">partition</dfn> as:</p>
<ul>
<li>A set of <a data-link-type="dfn" data-type="dfn" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/webappapis.html#environment">environments</a> (roughly iframes (including cross-site iframes), workers, and top-level
pages)</li>
<li>whose <a data-link-type="dfn" data-type="dfn" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/webappapis.html#concept-environment-top-level-origin">top-level origins</a> are in the <a data-link-type="dfn" data-type="dfn" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/origin.html#same-site">same site</a> (but see [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-psl-problems" title="Public Suffix List Problems">PSL-Problems</a></cite>])</li>
<li>being visited within the same user agent installation (and browser profile, container, or
container tab for user agents that support those features)</li>
<li>between points in time that the person or user agent clears that <a data-link-type="dfn" data-type="dfn" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/origin.html#site">site</a>'s cookies and other
storage (which is sometimes automatic at the end of each session).</li>
</ul>
<p>Even though this is the default, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-23">user agents</a> are free to restrict this context as
people need. For example, some user agents may help people present different
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-7">identities</a> to subdivisions of a single <a data-link-type="dfn" data-type="dfn" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/origin.html#site">site</a>.</p>
<div class="issue" id="issue-container-number-1"><div role="heading" class="issue-title marker" id="h-issue-2" aria-level="2"><a href="https://github.com/w3ctag/privacy-principles/issues/1"><span class="issue-number">Issue 1</span></a><span class="issue-label">: Figure out the default privacy boundary for the web</span></div><div class="">

<p>There is disagreement about whether <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-24">user agents</a> may also widen their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-machine-enforceable-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-machine-enforceable-context-1">machine-enforceable contexts</a>. For example, some user agents might want to help their users present a single
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-8">identity</a> to multiple <a data-link-type="dfn" data-type="dfn" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/origin.html#site">sites</a> that the user understands represent a single <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-13">party</a>, or to a
<a data-link-type="dfn" data-type="dfn" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/origin.html#site">site</a> across multiple installations.</p>
</div></div>

<p><a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-25">User agents</a> should prevent people from being <a data-link-type="dfn" data-lt="cross-context recognition" href="#dfn-cross-context-recognition" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-cross-context-recognition-2">recognized</a> across
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-machine-enforceable-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-machine-enforceable-context-2">machine-enforceable contexts</a> unless they intend to be recognized. This is a "should" rather
than a "must" because there are many cases where the user agent isn't powerful enough to prevent
recognition. For example if two or more services that a person needs to use insist that they share
a difficult-to-forge piece of their identity in order to use the services, it's the services
behaving <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-inappropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-inappropriately-5">inappropriately</a> rather than the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-26">user agent</a>.</p>
<p>If a <a data-link-type="dfn" data-type="dfn" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/origin.html#site">site</a> includes multiple <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-17">contexts</a> whose <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-20">principles</a> indicate that it's <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-inappropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-inappropriately-6">inappropriate</a> to
share data between the contexts, the fact that those distinct <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-18">contexts</a> fall inside a single
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-machine-enforceable-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-machine-enforceable-context-3">machine-enforceable context</a> doesn't make sharing data or <a data-link-type="dfn" data-lt="cross-context recognition" href="#dfn-cross-context-recognition" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-cross-context-recognition-3">recognizing</a> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-9">identities</a> any less <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-inappropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-inappropriately-7">inappropriate</a>.</p>
<section id="unwanted-cross-context-recognition"><div class="header-wrapper"><h4 id="hl-recognition-cross-context"><bdi class="secno">2.1.1 </bdi>Unwanted cross-context recognition</h4><a class="self-link" href="#hl-recognition-cross-context" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.1.1"></a></div><div class="issue" id="issue-container-generatedID-2"><div role="heading" class="issue-title marker" id="h-issue-3" aria-level="2"><span>Issue</span></div><aside class="">

<p>Merge this into its parent section on identity.</p>
</aside></div>

<p>Contributes to <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-surveillance" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-surveillance-1">surveillance</a>, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-correlation" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-correlation-1">correlation</a>, and <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identification" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identification-1">identification</a>.</p>
<p>As described in <a href="#identity" data-matched-text="[[[#identity]]]" class="sec-ref"><bdi class="secno">2.1 </bdi>Principles for Identity on the Web</a>, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-cross-context-recognition" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-cross-context-recognition-4">cross-context recognition</a> can sometimes be <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-appropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-appropriately-8">appropriate</a>, but
users need to be able to control when websites do it as much as possible.</p>
<div class="practice principle"><a class="marker self-link" href="#principle-prevent-cross-partition-recognition"><bdi lang="en">Principle</bdi></a>: <span class="practicelab" id="principle-prevent-cross-partition-recognition"><a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-27">User agents</a>
should ensure that, if a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-58">person</a> visits two or more web pages from different <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-partition" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-partition-1">partitions</a>, that
the pages cannot quickly determine that the visits probably came from the same person, for any
significant or involuntary fraction of the people who use the web, unless the person explicitly
expresses the same <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-10">identity</a> to the visits, or preventing this correlation would break a
technical feature that is fundamental to the Web.</span>

<p></p>

</div>

<ul>
<li>This principle uses "probably" because websites can do harm even if they can't be completely
certain that visits come from the same person.</li>
<li>This principle uses "quickly" because it currently appears impossible to prevent some forms of
fingerprinting that take a long time or many visits within each <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-partition" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-partition-2">partition</a>.</li>
<li>This principle is limited in cases that only affect a small fraction of people who use the web
because people may configure their systems in unique ways, for example by using
a browser with a very small number of users. As long as a tracker can't track a significant number
of people, it's likely to be unviable to maintain the tracker. However, this doesn't excuse making
small groups of people trackable when those people didn't choose to be in the group.</li>
<li>This principle is also limited in cases where preventing recognition would break fundamental
aspects of the web. In many cases it's possible to change the design in a way that avoids the
violation without breaking valid use cases, but for cases where that's not possible this document
delegates to other documents, for example the <cite><a data-matched-text="[[[Privacy-Threat]]]" href="https://w3cping.github.io/privacy-threat-model/">Target Privacy Threat Model</a></cite>, to discuss what detailed
tradeoffs to make.</li>
<li>This principle may not be able to be applied in situations where a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-59">person</a> has shared <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-11">identity</a>
information in a medium that is not accessible to the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-28">user agent</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p><a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-partition" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-partition-3">Partitions</a> are separated in two ways that lead to distinct kinds of user-visible recognition.
When their divisions between different sites are violated, that leads to <a href="#hl-recognition-cross-site" class="sec-ref"><bdi class="secno">2.1.1.2 </bdi>Unwanted cross-site recognition</a>. When a violation occurs at their other divisions, for
example between different browser profiles or at the point someone clears their cookies and site
storage, that leads to <a href="#hl-recognition-same-site" class="sec-ref"><bdi class="secno">2.1.1.1 </bdi>Same-site recognition</a>.</p>
<section id="same-site-recognition"><div class="header-wrapper"><h5 id="hl-recognition-same-site"><bdi class="secno">2.1.1.1 </bdi>Same-site recognition</h5><a class="self-link" href="#hl-recognition-same-site" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.1.1.1"></a></div><p>The web platform offers many ways for a website to recognize that a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-60">person</a> is using the same
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-12">identity</a> over time, including <cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-rfc6265" title="HTTP State Management Mechanism">cookies</a></cite>, <a data-link-type="idl" data-type="attribute" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/webstorage.html#dom-localstorage"><code>localStorage</code></a>,
<a data-link-type="idl" data-type="attribute" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/IndexedDB/#dom-windoworworkerglobalscope-indexeddb"><code>indexedDB</code></a>, <a data-link-type="idl" data-lt="CacheStorage" data-type="interface" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/service-workers-1/#cachestorage"><code>CacheStorage</code></a>, and other forms of storage. This allows
sites to save the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-61">person</a>'s preferences, shopping carts, etc., and people have come to expect this
behavior in some contexts.</p>
<p>A privacy harm occurs if a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-62">person</a> reasonably expects that they'll be using a different <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-13">identity</a>
on a site, but the site discovers and uses the fact that the two or more visits probably came from
the same <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-63">person</a> anyway.</p>
<p><a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-29">User agents</a> can't, in general, determine exactly where intra-site <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-19">context</a> boundaries are, or
how a site allows a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-64">person</a> to express that they intend to change <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-14">identities</a>, so they're not
responsible to enforce that sites actually separate <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-15">identities</a> at those boundaries. The <a href="#principle-prevent-cross-partition-recognition">principle</a> here instead requires separation
at <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-partition" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-partition-4">partition</a> boundaries.</p>
<p>Cross-<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-partition" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-partition-5">partition</a> recognition is generally accomplished by either "supercookies" or <a data-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/fingerprinting-guidance/#dfn-browser-fingerprinting">browser
fingerprinting</a>.</p>
<p>Supercookies occur when a browser stores data for a site but makes that data
more difficult to clear than other cookies or storage.
<a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/fingerprinting-guidance/#clearing-all-local-state">Fingerprinting
Guidance § Clearing all local state</a> discusses how specifications can help
browsers avoid this mistake.</p>
<p>Fingerprinting consists of using attributes of the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-65">person</a>'s browser and platform
that are consistent between two or more visits and probably unique to the
person.</p>
<p>The attributes can be exposed as information about the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-66">person</a>'s device that is
otherwise benign (as opposed to <a href="#hl-sensitive-information" data-matched-text="[[[#hl-sensitive-information]]]" class="sec-ref"><bdi class="secno">2.3 </bdi>Principles for Sensitive Information</a>). For example:</p>
<ul>
<li>What are the person's language and time zone?</li>
<li>What size is the window?</li>
<li>What system preferences have been set? Dark mode, serif font, etc...</li>
<li>...</li>
</ul>
<p>See [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-fingerprinting-guidance" title="Mitigating Browser Fingerprinting in Web Specifications">fingerprinting-guidance</a></cite>] for how to mitigate this threat.</p>
</section><section id="unwanted-cross-site-recognition"><div class="header-wrapper"><h5 id="hl-recognition-cross-site"><bdi class="secno">2.1.1.2 </bdi>Unwanted cross-site recognition</h5><a class="self-link" href="#hl-recognition-cross-site" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.1.1.2"></a></div><p>A privacy harm occurs if a site determines with high probability and uses the fact that a visit to
that site comes from the same person as another visit to a <em>different</em> site, unless the person could
reasonably expect the sites to discover this. Traditionally, sites have accomplished this using <a href="https://tess.oconnor.cx/2020/10/parties#environment-cross-site">cross-site</a> cookies, but it
can also be done by having someone navigate to a link that has been decorated with an identifier,
collecting the same piece of identifying information on both sites, or by correlating the timestamps
of an event that occurs nearly-simultaneously on both sites.</p>
