</section></section></section><section id="principles-for-personal-data"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="data"><bdi class="secno">2.2 </bdi>Principles for Personal Data</h3><a class="self-link" href="#data" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.2"></a></div><div class="issue" id="issue-container-generatedID-3"><div role="heading" class="issue-title marker" id="h-issue-4" aria-level="2"><span>Issue</span></div><aside class="">


<p>  This section has not been edited for narrative.</p>
</aside></div>

<p>We define <dfn data-lt="data|personal data" id="dfn-data" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">personal data</dfn> as any information that is directly or
indirectly related to an identified or identifiable <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-67">person</a>, such as by reference to an
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identifier" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identifier-4">identifier</a> ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-gdpr" title="General Data Protection Regulations (GDPR) / Regulation (EU) 2016/679">GDPR</a></cite>], [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-oecd-guidelines" title="OECD Guidelines on the Protection of Privacy and Transborder Flows of Personal Data">OECD-Guidelines</a></cite>], [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-convention-108" title="Convention for the Protection of Individuals with regard to Automatic Processing of Personal Data">Convention-108</a></cite>]).</p>
<p>If a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-68">person</a> could reasonably be identified or re-identified when <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-13">data</a> is combined with other
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-14">data</a>, then that makes that data <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-15">personal data</a>.</p>
<section id="data-users-and-use"><div class="header-wrapper"><h4 id="data-users"><bdi class="secno">2.2.1 </bdi>Data users and use</h4><a class="self-link" href="#data-users" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.2.1"></a></div><p>A <dfn data-lt="data processor|service provider" data-plurals="service providers" id="dfn-data-processor" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">service provider</dfn> or <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data-processor" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-processor-1">data processor</a> is considered to be the same
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-14">party</a> as the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-actors" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-actors-9">actor</a> contracting it to perform the relevant <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-19">processing</a> if it:</p>
<ul>
<li>is processing the data on behalf of that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-15">party</a>;</li>
<li>ensures that the data is only retained, accessed, and used as directed by that
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-16">party</a> and solely for the list of explicitly-specified <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-purpose" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-purpose-7">purposes</a>
detailed by the directing <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-17">party</a> or <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data-controller" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-controller-1">data controller</a>;</li>
<li>may determine implementation details of the data processing in question but
does not determine the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-purpose" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-purpose-8">purpose</a> for which the data is being <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-20">processed</a>
nor the overarching <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-means" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-means-1">means</a> through which the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-purpose" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-purpose-9">purpose</a> is carried out;</li>
<li>has no independent right to use the data other than in a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-de-identified" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-de-identified-3">de-identified</a> form (e.g., for
monitoring service integrity, load balancing, capacity planning, or billing); and,</li>
<li>has a contract in place with the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-18">party</a> which is consistent with the above limitations.</li>
</ul>
<p>A <dfn id="dfn-data-controller" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">data controller</dfn> is a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-19">party</a> that determines the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-means" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-means-2">means</a> and <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-purpose" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-purpose-10">purposes</a>
of data processing. Any <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-20">party</a> that is not a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data-processor" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-processor-2">service provider</a> is a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data-controller" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-controller-2">data controller</a>.</p>
</section><section id="techniques"><div class="header-wrapper"><h4 id="data-techniques"><bdi class="secno">2.2.2 </bdi>Techniques</h4><a class="self-link" href="#data-techniques" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.2.2"></a></div><p>The <dfn id="dfn-vegas-rule" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">Vegas Rule</dfn> is a simple implementation of privacy in which "<i>what happens with the
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-first-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-first-parties-2">first party</a> stays with the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-first-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-first-parties-3">first party</a></i>." Put differently, the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-vegas-rule" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-vegas-rule-1">Vegas Rule</a> is followed
when the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-first-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-first-parties-4">first party</a> is the only <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data-controller" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-controller-3">data controller</a>. While the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-vegas-rule" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-vegas-rule-2">Vegas Rule</a> is a good
guideline, it's neither necessary nor sufficient for <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-appropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-appropriately-9">appropriate</a> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-21">data processing</a>. A <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-first-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-first-parties-5">first party</a> that maintains exclusive access to a person's data can still <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-22">process</a> it
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-inappropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-inappropriately-8">inappropriately</a>, and there are cases where a third party can learn information about a person
but still treat it <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-appropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-appropriately-10">appropriately</a>.</p>
<section id="de-identification"><div class="header-wrapper"><h5 id="x2-2-2-1-de-identification"><bdi class="secno">2.2.2.1 </bdi>De-identification</h5><a class="self-link" href="#de-identification" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.2.2.1"></a></div>
<p>Data is <dfn id="dfn-de-identified" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">de-identified</dfn> when there exists a high level of confidence
that no <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-69">person</a> described by the data can be identified, directly or indirectly
(e.g. via association with an <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identifier" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identifier-5">identifier</a>, user agent, or device), by that data alone or in
combination with other available information. Note
that further considerations relating to groups are covered in the
<a href="#collective">Collective Issues in Privacy</a> section.</p>
<p>We talk of <dfn id="dfn-controlled-de-identified-data" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">controlled de-identified data</dfn> when there are strict controls that prevent the
re-identification of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-70">people</a> described by the data except for a well-defined set of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-purpose" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-purpose-11">purposes</a>.</p>
<p>Different situations involving <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-controlled-de-identified-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-controlled-de-identified-data-1">controlled de-identified data</a> will require different controls. For instance,
if the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-controlled-de-identified-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-controlled-de-identified-data-2">controlled de-identified data</a> is <em>only</em> being processed by one <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-21">party</a>, typical controls
include making sure that the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identifier" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identifier-6">identifiers</a> used in the data are unique to that dataset, that
any person (e.g. an employee of the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-22">party</a>) with access to the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-16">data</a> is barred (e.g. based on
legal terms) from sharing the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-17">data</a> further, and that technical measures exist to prevent
re-identification or the joining of different data sets involving this <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-18">data</a>, notably against
timing or k-anonymity attacks.</p>
<p>In general, the goal is to ensure that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-controlled-de-identified-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-controlled-de-identified-data-3">controlled de-identified data</a> is used in a manner that provides a
viable degree of oversight and accountability such that technical and procedural means to guarantee
the maintenance of pseudonymity are preserved.</p>
<p>This is more difficult when the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-controlled-de-identified-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-controlled-de-identified-data-4">controlled de-identified data</a> is shared between several <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-23">parties</a>. In such
cases, good examples of typical controls that are representative of best practices would include
making sure that:</p>
<ul>
<li><p>the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identifier" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identifier-7">identifiers</a> used in the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-19">data</a> are under the direct and exclusive control of
the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-first-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-first-parties-6">first party</a> who is prevented by strict controls from matching the identifiers with the
data;</p>
</li>
<li><p>when these <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identifier" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identifier-8">identifiers</a> are shared with a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-third-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-third-parties-1">third party</a>, they are made unique
to that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-third-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-third-parties-2">third party</a> such that if they are shared with more than one
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-third-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-third-parties-3">third party</a> these cannot then match them up with one another;</p>
</li>
<li><p>there is a strong level of confidence that no <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-third-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-third-parties-4">third party</a> can match the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-20">data</a>
with any data other than that obtained through interactions with the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-first-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-first-parties-7">first party</a>;</p>
</li>
<li><p>any <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-third-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-third-parties-5">third party</a> receiving such <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-21">data</a> is barred (eg. based on legal terms)
from sharing it further;</p>
</li>
<li><p>technical measures exist to prevent re-identification or the joining of
different data sets involving this <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-22">data</a>, notably against timing or
k-anonymity attacks; and</p>
</li>
<li><p>there exist contractual terms between the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-first-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-first-parties-8">first party</a> and <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-third-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-third-parties-6">third party</a>
describing the limited <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-purpose" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-purpose-12">purpose</a> for which the data is being shared.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Note that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-controlled-de-identified-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-controlled-de-identified-data-5">controlled de-identified data</a>, on its own, is not sufficient to render <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-23">data processing</a>
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-appropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-appropriately-11">appropriate</a>.</p>
</section></section><section id="rights"><div class="header-wrapper"><h4 id="data-rights"><bdi class="secno">2.2.3 </bdi>Rights</h4><a class="self-link" href="#data-rights" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.2.3"></a></div><p><a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-71">People</a> retain certain rights over data about themselves, and these rights should be facilitated
by their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-30">user agent</a> and the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-24">parties</a> they're interacting with. While data rights alone are
not sufficient to satisfy all <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-privacy" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-privacy-6">privacy</a> principles for the Web, they do support self-determination
and help improve accountability. Such rights include:</p>
<ul>
<li>The <dfn data-export="" id="dfn-right-to-access" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">right to access</dfn> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-23">data</a> about oneself.</li>
</ul>
<p>This right includes being able to discover data about oneself (implying no databases are kept
secret) and to review
what information has been collected or inferred.</p>
<ul>
<li>The <dfn data-export="" data-lt="right to erase" id="dfn-right-to-erase" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">right to erase</dfn> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-24">data</a> about oneself.</li>
</ul>
<p>The right to erase applies whether or not terminating use of a service altogether, though what
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-25">data</a> can be erased may differ between those two cases. On the Web, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-72">people</a> may wish to erase
data on their device, on a server, or both, and the distinctions may not always be clear.</p>
<ul>
<li>The <dfn data-export="" data-lt="right to portability|right to port|portability" data-local-lt="portability" id="dfn-right-to-portability" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">right to
port</dfn> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-26">data</a>, including data one has stored with a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-25">party</a>, so it can easily be reused or
transferred elsewhere.</li>
</ul>
<p>Portability is needed to realize the ability for <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-73">people</a> to make choices about services with
different data practices. Standards for interoperability are essential for effective re-use.</p>
<ul>
<li><p>The <dfn data-export="" id="dfn-right-to-correct" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">right to correct</dfn> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-27">data</a> about oneself, to ensure that one's
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-16">identity</a> is properly reflected in a system.</p>
</li>
<li><p>The <dfn data-export="" id="dfn-right-to-be-free-from-automated-decision-making" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">right to be free from automated decision-making</dfn> based on <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-28">data</a>
about oneself.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>For some kinds of decision-making with substantial consequences, there is a privacy interest in
being able to exclude oneself from automated profiling. For example, some services may alter the
price of products (price discrimination) or offers for credit or insurance based on <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-29">data</a>
collected about a person. Those alterations may be consequential (financially, say) and
objectionable to people who believe those decisions based on data about them are inaccurate or
unjust. As another example, some services may draw inferences about a user's identity, humanity or
presence based on facial recognition algorithms run on camera data. Because facial recognition
algorithms and training sets are fallible and may exhibit certain biases, people may not wish to
submit to decisions based on that kind of automated recognition.</p>
<ul>
<li>The <dfn data-export="" data-lt="right to object|right to withdraw consent|right to restrict use|right to object, withdraw consent, and restrict use" id="dfn-right-to-object" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">right to object,
withdraw consent, and restrict use</dfn> of data about oneself.</li>
</ul>
<p><a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-74">People</a> may change their decisions about consent or may object to subsequent uses of data about
themselves. Retaining rights requires ongoing control, not just at the time of collection.</p>
<p>The OECD Privacy Principles [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-oecd-guidelines" title="OECD Guidelines on the Protection of Privacy and Transborder Flows of Personal Data">OECD-Guidelines</a></cite>], [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-records-computers-rights" title="Records, Computers and the Rights of Citizens">Records-Computers-Rights</a></cite>], and the [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-gdpr" title="General Data Protection Regulations (GDPR) / Regulation (EU) 2016/679">GDPR</a></cite>],
among other places, include many of the rights <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-75">people</a> have as data subjects. These participatory
rights by people over data about themselves are inherent to <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-autonomous" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-autonomous-11">autonomy</a>.</p>
</section></section><section id="principles-for-sensitive-information"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="hl-sensitive-information"><bdi class="secno">2.3 </bdi>Principles for Sensitive Information</h3><a class="self-link" href="#hl-sensitive-information" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.3"></a></div><p>Contributes to <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-correlation" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-correlation-2">correlation</a>, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identification" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identification-2">identification</a>, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-secondary-use" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-secondary-use-1">secondary use</a>, and
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-disclosure" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-disclosure-1">disclosure</a>.</p>
<p>Many pieces of information about someone could cause privacy harms if disclosed.
For example:</p>
<ul>
<li>Their location.</li>
<li>Video or audio from the their camera or microphone.</li>
<li>The content of certain files on their filesystem.</li>
<li>Financial data.</li>
<li>Contacts.</li>
<li>Calendar entries.</li>
<li><a href="https://w3ctag.github.io/design-principles/#do-not-expose-use-of-assistive-tech">Whether they are using assistive technology.</a></li>
<li>...</li>
</ul>
<p>A particular piece of information may have different sensitivity for different
people. Language preferences, for example, might typically seem innocent, but
also can be an indicator of belonging to an ethnic minority. Precise location
information can be extremely sensitive (because it's identifying, because it
allows for in-person intrusions, because it can reveal detailed information
about a person's life) but it might also be public and not sensitive at all, or
it might be low-enough granularity that it is much less sensitive for many
people.</p>
<p>When considering whether a class of information is likely to be sensitive to
a person, consider at least these factors:</p>
<ul>
<li>whether it serves as a persistent <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identifier" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identifier-9">identifier</a> (see severity in Mitigating
  browser fingerprinting);</li>
<li>whether it discloses substantial (including intimate details or inferences)
  information about the the person using the system or other people;</li>
<li>whether it can be revoked (as in determining whether a permission is
  necessary);</li>
<li>whether it enables other threats, like intrusion.</li>
</ul>
<p>Issue(16): This description of what makes information sensitive still needs to
be refined.</p>
</section><section id="principles-for-profiling"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="hl-unexpected-profiling"><bdi class="secno">2.4 </bdi>Principles for Profiling</h3><a class="self-link" href="#hl-unexpected-profiling" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.4"></a></div><div class="issue" id="issue-container-generatedID-4"><div role="heading" class="issue-title marker" id="h-issue-5" aria-level="2"><span>Issue</span></div><aside class="">


<p>  This section has not been edited for narrative.</p>
</aside></div>

<p>Contributes to <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-surveillance" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-surveillance-2">surveillance</a>, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-correlation" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-correlation-3">correlation</a>, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identification" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identification-3">identification</a>, and
singling-out / discrimination.</p>
<p>Unexpected profiling occurs when a site is able to learn attributes or
characteristics about a person, that a) the site visitor did not intend the site
to learn, and b) the site visitor reasonably could not anticipate a
site would be able to learn.</p>
<p>Profiling contributes to, but is distinct from, other privacy risks discussed
in this document.
For example, unexpected profiling may contribute to
<a href="#hl-recognition-same-site" data-matched-text="[[[#hl-recognition-same-site]]]" class="sec-ref"><bdi class="secno">2.1.1.1 </bdi>Same-site recognition</a>, by adding stable and semi-identifying
information that can contribute to <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/fingerprinting-guidance/#dfn-browser-fingerprinting">browser
fingerprinting</a>. Unexpected profiling is distinct from same-site
recognition though, in that a person may wish to not share some kinds
of information about themselves <em>even in the presence of guarantees
that such information will not lead to them being re-identified</em>.</p>
<p>Similarly, unexpected profiling is related to <a href="#hl-sensitive-information" data-matched-text="[[[#hl-sensitive-information]]]" class="sec-ref"><bdi class="secno">2.3 </bdi>Principles for Sensitive Information</a>,
but the former is a superset of the latter;
all cases of unexpected sensitive information disclosure are examples of
unexpected profiling, but people using the Web may have attributes or characteristics
about themselves that are not universally thought of as "sensitive", but which
they never the less do not wish to share with the sites they visit. People
may wish to not share these "non-sensitive" characteristics
for a variety of reasons (e.g., a person may worry that their ideas of what
counts as "sensitive" is different from others, a person might might be ashamed
or uncomfortable about a character trait or they might simply not wish to be profiled).</p>
<p>Profiling occurs for many reasons. It can be used to facilitate price
discrimination or offer manipulation, to make inferences about what products or
services people might be more likely to purchase, or more generally, for a site
to learn attributes about them that they do not intend to share.
Unexpected profiling can also contribute to feelings of powerlessness and
loss of agency [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-privacy-concerned" title="Americans and Privacy: Concerned, Confused and Feeling Lack of Control Over Their Personal Information">Privacy-Concerned</a></cite>].</p>
<p>A privacy harm occurs if a site learns information about a person that they
reasonably expected the site would not be able to learn, regardless of
whether that information aids (re)identification or is from a sensitive category
of information (however defined).</p>
<div class="example">

<p>Peter is a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Furry_fandom">furry</a>.
Despite knowing that there are thousands of
other furries on the internet, and despite using a browser with
robust browser fingerprinting protections, and despite the growing cultural
acceptance of furries, Peter does not want (most) sites to learn
or personalize content around his furry-interest.</p>
</div>

</section><section id="collective-privacy-0"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="collective-privacy"><bdi class="secno">2.5 </bdi>Collective Privacy</h3><a class="self-link" href="#collective-privacy" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.5"></a></div><div class="practice principle"><a class="marker self-link" href="#principle-collective-privacy"><bdi lang="en">Principle</bdi></a>: <span class="practicelab" id="principle-collective-privacy">
    Groups and various forms of institutions should best protect and support autonomy by making
    decisions collectively rather than individually to either prevent or enable data
    sharing, and to set defaults for data processing rules.
  </span>

<p>
  
</p>

</div>

<p>Privacy principles are often defined in terms of extending rights to individuals. However, there are
cases in which deciding which principles apply is best done collectively, on behalf of a group.</p>
<p>One such case, which has become increasingly common with widespread profiling, is that of information
relating to membership of a group or to a group's behaviour, as detailed in
<a href="#group-privacy" class="sec-ref"><bdi class="secno">1.2.1 </bdi>Group Privacy</a>. As Brent Mittelstadt explains, “<em>Algorithmically grouped
individuals have a collective interest in the creation of information about the group, and actions
taken on its behalf.</em>” ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-individual-group-privacy" title="From Individual to Group Privacy in Big Data Analytics">Individual-Group-Privacy</a></cite>]) This justifies ensuring that grouped
people can benefit from both individual and collective means to support their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-autonomous" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-autonomous-12">autonomy</a> with respect
to <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-30">data</a> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-24">processing</a>. It should be noted that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-25">processing</a> can be unjust even if individuals
remain anonymous, not from the violation of individual <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-autonomous" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-autonomous-13">autonomy</a> but because it violates ideals
of social equality ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-relational-governance" title="A Relational Theory of Data Governance">Relational-Governance</a></cite>]).</p>
<p>Another case in which collective decision-making is preferable is for <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-26">processing</a> for which
informed individual decision-making is unrealistic (due to the complexity of the processing, the
volume or frequency of processing, or both). Expecting laypeople (or even experts) to make informed
decisions relating to complex <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-31">data</a> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-27">processing</a> or to make decisions on a very frequent basis
even if the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-28">processing</a> is relatively simple, is unrealistic if we also want them to have
reasonable levels of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-autonomous" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-autonomous-14">autonomy</a> in making these decisions.</p>
<p>The purpose of this principle is to require that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-governance" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-governance-4">data governance</a> provide ways to distinguish
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-appropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-appropriately-12">appropriate</a> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-32">data</a> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-29">processing</a> without relying on individual decisions whenever the latter
are impossible, which is often ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-relational-governance" title="A Relational Theory of Data Governance">Relational-Governance</a></cite>], [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-relational-turn" title="A Relational Turn for Data Protection?">Relational-Turn</a></cite>]).</p>
<p>Which forms of collective governance are recognised as legitimate will depend on domains. These may
take many forms, such as governmental bodies at various administrative levels, standards
organisations, worker bargaining units, or civil society fora.</p>
<p>It must be noted that, even though collective decision-making can be better than offloading
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-privacy-labor" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-privacy-labor-5">privacy labour</a> to <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-76">individuals</a>, it is not necessarily a panacea. When considering such
collective arrangements it is important to keep in mind the principles that are likely to support
viable and effective institutions at any level of complexity ([<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-iad" title="Understanding Institutional Diversity">IAD</a></cite>]).</p>
<p>A good example of a failure in collective privacy decisions was the standardisation of the
<code><a data-type="element-attr" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/links.html#ping">ping</a></code> attribute. Search engines, social sites, and other algorithmic media in the same vein
have an interest in knowing which sites that they link to <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-77">people</a> choose to visit (which in turn
could improve the service for everyone). But <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-78">people</a> may have an interest in keeping that
information private from algorithmic media companies (as do the sites being linked to, as that
facilitates timing attacks to recognise <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-79">people</a> there). A <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-80">person</a>'s exit through a specific
link can either be tracked with JavaScript tricks or through bounce tracking, both of which are slow
and difficult for user agents to defend against. The value proposition of the <code><a data-type="element-attr" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/links.html#ping">ping</a></code> attribute
in this context is therefore straightforward: by providing declarative support for this
functionality it can be made fast (the browser sends an asynchronous notification to a ping
endpoint after the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-81">person</a> exits through a link) and the user agent can provide its <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-82">user</a> with
the option to opt out of such tracking — or disable it by default.</p>
<p>Unfortunately, this arrangement proved to be unworkable on the privacy side (the performance gains,
however, are real). What prevents a site from using <code><a data-type="element-attr" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/links.html#ping">ping</a></code> for <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-83">people</a> who have it activated
and bounce tracking for others? What prevents a browsers from opting everyone out because it wishes
to offer better protection by default? Given the contested nature of the <code><a data-type="element-attr" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/links.html#ping">ping</a></code> attribute and
the absence of a forcing function to support collective enforcement, the scheme failed to deliver
improved privacy.</p>
</section><section id="principles-for-safety-systems"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="safety"><bdi class="secno">2.6 </bdi>Principles for Safety Systems</h3><a class="self-link" href="#safety" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.6"></a></div><div class="issue" id="issue-container-generatedID-5"><div role="heading" class="issue-title marker" id="h-issue-6" aria-level="2"><span>Issue</span></div><aside class="">


<p>  This section has not been edited for narrative.</p>
</aside></div>


<div class="issue" id="issue-container-number-73"><div role="heading" class="issue-title marker" id="h-issue-7" aria-level="2"><a href="https://github.com/w3ctag/privacy-principles/issues/73"><span class="issue-number">Issue 73</span></a><span class="issue-label">: How do safety systems relate to privacy <a class="respec-gh-label" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/privacy-principles/issues/?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3A%22agenda%2B%22" style="background-color: rgb(245, 169, 184); color: rgb(0, 0, 0);" aria-label="GitHub label: agenda+">agenda+</a></span></div><aside class="">

<p>Discuss how systems intended to protect a person might justifiably collect more data from
that person and from people who might be trying to attack that person. Also discuss
whether systems intended to protect server-side parties from abuse can collect more data
from users.</p>
<p>Discuss what limits need to be placed on such practices to distinguish them from privatised
law enforcement and intellligence agencies.</p>
</aside></div>


</section><section id="principles-for-guardians-and-device-owners"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="guardians-and-owners"><bdi class="secno">2.7 </bdi>Principles for Guardians and Device Owners</h3><a class="self-link" href="#guardians-and-owners" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.7"></a></div><div class="issue" id="issue-container-number-2"><div role="heading" class="issue-title marker" id="h-issue-8" aria-level="2"><a href="https://github.com/w3ctag/privacy-principles/issues/2"><span class="issue-number">Issue 2</span></a><span class="issue-label">: Address device owners <a class="respec-gh-label" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/privacy-principles/issues/?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3A%22agenda%2B%22" style="background-color: rgb(245, 169, 184); color: rgb(0, 0, 0);" aria-label="GitHub label: agenda+">agenda+</a></span></div><p dir="auto">Most of our thinking about stakeholders on the web follows the <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/html-design-principles/#priority-of-constituencies" rel="nofollow">priority of constituencies</a>: we consider users, authors, implementors, and specifiers. Sometimes we also consider <a href="https://w3ctag.github.io/ethical-web-principles/#noharm" rel="nofollow">society</a> or national governments. In <a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="802499101" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/606" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/606/hovercard" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/606">w3ctag/design-reviews#606</a> and other enterprise-focused designs we need to address device owners or administrators, and I haven't been able to find any W3C discussion of how to consider them.</p>
<p dir="auto">This is a broader question than just the privacy principles we're working on here, but some of the answer belongs here. We should say something about the power dynamics of employees, children, romantic partners, etc. who have to use devices owned by other people who might not always have their best interests in mind, and how the UA is responsible to protect the user while also respecting whatever rights the device owner ought to have.</p></div>

</section><section id="principles-for-harassment"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="x2-8-principles-for-harassment"><bdi class="secno">2.8 </bdi>Principles for Harassment</h3><a class="self-link" href="#principles-for-harassment" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.8"></a></div>
<div class="issue" id="issue-container-generatedID-6"><div role="heading" class="issue-title marker" id="h-issue-9" aria-level="2"><span>Issue</span></div><aside class="">


<p>  This section has not been written.</p>
</aside></div>

</section><section id="unwanted-information-0"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="unwanted-information"><bdi class="secno">2.9 </bdi>Unwanted Information</h3><a class="self-link" href="#unwanted-information" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.9"></a></div><p>Receiving unsolicited information that either may cause distress or waste the recipient's
time or resources is a violation of privacy. </p>
<div class="practice principle"><a class="marker self-link" href="#principle-protect-unwanted-information"><bdi lang="en">Principle</bdi></a>: <span class="practicelab" id="principle-protect-unwanted-information">
    <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-31">User agents</a> and other <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-actors" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-actors-10">actors</a> should take
    steps to ensure that their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-84">user</a> is not exposed to unwanted information. Technical standards
    must consider the delivery of unwanted information as part of their architecture and must
    mitigate it accordingly.
  </span>

<p>
  
</p>
</div>

<p>Unwanted information covers a broad range of unsolicited communication, from messages that are
typically harmless individually but that become a nuisance in aggregate (spam) to the sending of
images that will cause shock or disgust due to their graphic, violent, or explicit nature (eg.
pictures of one's genitals). While it is impossible, in a communication system involving many
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-85">people</a>, to offer perfect protection against all kinds of unwanted information, steps can be
taken to make the sending of such messages more difficult or more costly, and to render the senders
more accountable. Examples of mitigations include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Restricting what new users of a service can post, notably limiting links and media until they have
interacted a sufficient number of times over a given period with a larger group. This helps to
raise the cost of producing sockpuppet accounts and gives new users the occasion to understand
local norms before posting.</li>
<li>Only accepting communication between <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-86">people</a> who have an established relationship of some kind,
such as being part of a shared group. Protocols should consider requiring a handshake between
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-87">people</a> prior to enabling communication.</li>
<li>Requiring a deliberate action from the recipient before rendering media coming from an
untrusted source.</li>
<li>Supporting the ability for <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-88">people</a> to block a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-26">party</a> such that they cannot send information
again.</li>
<li>Pooling mitigation information, for instance shared block lists, shared spam-detection
information, or public information about misbehaving <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-actors" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-actors-11">actors</a>. As always, the collection and
sharing of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-information" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-information-9">information</a> for safety purposes should be limited and placed under collective
governance.</li>
</ul>
</section><section id="principles-for-vulnerable-people"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="x2-10-principles-for-vulnerable-people"><bdi class="secno">2.10 </bdi>Principles for Vulnerable People</h3><a class="self-link" href="#principles-for-vulnerable-people" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.10"></a></div>
<div class="issue" id="issue-container-generatedID-7"><div role="heading" class="issue-title marker" id="h-issue-10" aria-level="2"><span>Issue</span></div><aside class="">


<p>  This section has not been written.</p>
</aside></div>


</section><section id="principles-for-consent-withdrawal-of-consent-opt-outs-and-objections"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="consent-principles"><bdi class="secno">2.11 </bdi>Principles for Consent, Withdrawal of Consent, Opt-Outs, and Objections</h3><a class="self-link" href="#consent-principles" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.11"></a></div><div class="practice principle"><a class="marker self-link" href="#principle-consent-user-preference"><bdi lang="en">Principle</bdi></a>: <span class="practicelab" id="principle-consent-user-preference">
    When any <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-actors" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-actors-12">actor</a> obtains <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-opt-in" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-opt-in-13">consent</a> for processing from a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-89">person</a>, the
    actor should design the consent request so as to learn the person's true
    intent to consent or not, and not to maximize the processing consented to.
  </span>
<p>
  
</p>
</div>

<p>Attempts to obtain consent to <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-30">processing</a> that is not in accordance with the person's
true preferences result in imposing unwanted <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-privacy-labor" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-privacy-labor-6">privacy labour</a> on the person, and may
result in people erroneously giving consent that they regret later.</p>
<div class="practice principle"><a class="marker self-link" href="#principle-minimize-consent-requests"><bdi lang="en">Principle</bdi></a>: <span class="practicelab" id="principle-minimize-consent-requests">
    An <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-actors" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-actors-13">actor</a> should avoid interrupting a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-90">person</a>'s use of a site for
    consent requests when an alternative is available.
  </span>
<p>
  
</p>
</div>

<p>Examples of alternatives to interrupting users with consent requests include:</p>
<ul>
<li><p>Considering the information sharing norms in the site's audience
and category, and requesting only consent that is appropriate
to the purpose of the site. (For example, a photo sharing site's
users might expect to be prompted for consent to share their
uploaded work.)  Sites should consider conducting user research on
people's expectations for how data is processed.</p>
</li>
<li><p>Relying on a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-global-opt-out" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-global-opt-out-5">global opt-out</a> signal from the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-32">user agent</a>.</p>
</li>
<li><p>Delaying a prompt for consent until a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-91">user</a> does something that puts the request in context,
 which will also help them give an informed response.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="practice principle"><a class="marker self-link" href="#principle-consent-withdraw"><bdi lang="en">Principle</bdi></a>: <span class="practicelab" id="principle-consent-withdraw">
    It should be as easy for a user to check what consent they have given,
    to withdraw consent, or to opt out or object,
    as to give consent.
  </span>
<p>
  
</p>
</div>


</section><section id="principles-for-notifications-and-interruptions"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="x2-12-principles-for-notifications-and-interruptions"><bdi class="secno">2.12 </bdi>Principles for Notifications and Interruptions</h3><a class="self-link" href="#principles-for-notifications-and-interruptions" aria-label="Permalink for Section 2.12"></a></div>
<div class="issue" id="issue-container-generatedID-8"><div role="heading" class="issue-title marker" id="h-issue-11" aria-level="2"><span>Issue</span></div><aside class="">

<p>Connect intrusiveness to <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-autonomous" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-autonomous-15">autonomy</a>, and write some principles.</p>
</aside></div>




</section></section><section class="appendix" id="common-concepts"><div class="header-wrapper"><h2 id="boring-terminology"><bdi class="secno">A. </bdi>Common Concepts</h2><a class="self-link" href="#boring-terminology" aria-label="Permalink for Appendix A."></a></div>

<section id="people-0"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="people"><bdi class="secno">A.1 </bdi>People</h3><a class="self-link" href="#people" aria-label="Permalink for Appendix A.1"></a></div><p>A <dfn data-lt="individual|people|user|data subject|person" data-plurals="individuals" id="dfn-individual" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">person</dfn> (also <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-92">user</a> or
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-93">data subject</a>) is any natural person. Throughout this document, we primarily use <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-94">person</a> or
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-95">people</a> to refer to human beings, as a reminder of their humanity. When we use the term <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-96">user</a>,
it is to talk about the specific <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-97">person</a> who happens to be using a given system at that time.</p>
<p>A <dfn data-lt="vulnerable|vulnerable person" id="dfn-vulnerable" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">vulnerable person</dfn> is a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-98">person</a> who may be unable to
exercise sufficient self-determination in a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-20">context</a>. Amongst other things, they should
be treated with greater default privacy protections and may be considered unable to
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-opt-in" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-opt-in-14">consent</a> to various interactions with a system.
People can be vulnerable for different reasons, for example because they are children,
are employees with respect to their employers, are facing a steep asymmetry of power,
are people in some situations of intellectual or psychological impairment, are
refugees, etc.</p>
<p>A <dfn data-plurals="contexts" id="dfn-context" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">context</dfn> is a physical or digital environment that a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-99">person</a> interacts with
for a set of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-purpose" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-purpose-13">purposes</a> (that they typically share with other <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-100">people</a> who interact with the
same environment).</p>
</section><section id="server-side-parties"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="parties"><bdi class="secno">A.2 </bdi>Server-Side Parties</h3><a class="self-link" href="#parties" aria-label="Permalink for Appendix A.2"></a></div><p>A <dfn data-plurals="parties" id="dfn-party" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">party</dfn> is an entity that a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-101">person</a> can reasonably understand as a single "thing"
they're interacting with. Uses of this document in a particular domain are expected to describe how
the core concepts of that domain combine into a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-102">user</a>-comprehensible <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-27">party</a>, and those refined
definitions are likely to differ between domains.</p>
<p>The <dfn data-lt="first parties|first party" id="dfn-first-parties" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">first party</dfn> is a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-28">party</a> with which a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-103">person</a> intends to
interact. Merely hovering over, muting, pausing, or closing a given piece of content does
not mean a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-104">person</a> intends to interact with another party, nor does the simple
fact of loading a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-29">party</a> embedded in the one with which the person intends to
interact. In cases of clear and conspicuous joint branding, there can be multiple <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-first-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-first-parties-9">first parties</a>. The <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-first-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-first-parties-10">first party</a> is necessarily a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data-controller" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-controller-4">data controller</a> of the data processing
that takes places as a consequence of a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-105">person</a> interacting with it.</p>
<div class="issue" id="issue-container-generatedID-9"><div role="heading" class="issue-title marker" id="h-issue-12" aria-level="3"><span>Issue</span></div><aside class="">

<p>Refine the description of third parties so it matches
intuition better.</p>
</aside></div>

<p>A <dfn data-lt="third parties|third party" id="dfn-third-parties" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">third party</dfn> is any <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-30">party</a> other than the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-106">person</a> visiting the website,
the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-first-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-first-parties-11">first party</a>, or a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data-processor" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-processor-3">service provider</a> acting on behalf of either the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-107">person</a> or
the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-first-parties" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-first-parties-12">first party</a>.</p>
</section><section id="acting-on-data-0"><div class="header-wrapper"><h3 id="acting-on-data"><bdi class="secno">A.3 </bdi>Acting on Data</h3><a class="self-link" href="#acting-on-data" aria-label="Permalink for Appendix A.3"></a></div><p><dfn id="dfn-privacy" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">Privacy</dfn> is achieved in a given <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-21">context</a> that either involves <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-33">personal data</a> or
involves information being presented to <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-108">people</a> when the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-21">principles</a> of that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-22">context</a> are
followed appropriately. When the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-22">principles</a> for that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-23">context</a> are not followed, there is a
<dfn id="dfn-privacy-violation" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">privacy violation</dfn>. Similarly, we say that a particular interaction is
<dfn data-lt="appropriately|appropriate" id="dfn-appropriately" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">appropriate</dfn> when the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-principles" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-principles-23">principles</a> are adhered
to) or <dfn data-lt="inappropriately|inappropriate" id="dfn-inappropriately" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">inappropriate</dfn> otherwise.</p>
<p>A <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-31">party</a> <dfn data-lt="process|processing|processed|data processing|processes" id="dfn-process" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">processes</dfn> data if it
carries out operations on <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-34">personal data</a>, whether or not by automated means, such as
collection, recording, organisation, structuring, storage, adaptation or alteration,
retrieval, consultation, use, disclosure by transmission, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-share" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-share-1">sharing</a>, dissemination or
otherwise making available, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-sell" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-sell-1">selling</a>, alignment or combination, restriction, erasure or
destruction.</p>
<p>A <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-32">party</a> <dfn data-lt="share|sharing|shares" id="dfn-share" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">shares</dfn> data if it provides it to any other
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-33">party</a>. Note that, under this definition, a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-34">party</a> that provides data to its own
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-data-processor" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-data-processor-4">service providers</a> is not <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-share" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-share-2">sharing</a> it.</p>
<p>A <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-party" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-party-35">party</a> <dfn data-lt="sell|selling|sells" id="dfn-sell" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">sells</dfn> data when it <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-share" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-share-3">shares</a> it in exchange
for consideration, monetary or otherwise.</p>
<p>The <dfn data-plurals="purposes" id="dfn-purpose" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">purpose</dfn> of a given <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-31">processing</a> of data is an anticipated, intended, or
planned outcome of this <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-32">processing</a> which is achieved or aimed for within a given
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-24">context</a>. A <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-purpose" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-purpose-14">purpose</a>, when described, should be specific enough to be actionable by
someone familiar with the relevant <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-25">context</a> (ie. they could independently determine
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-means" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-means-3">means</a> that reasonably correspond to an implementation of the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-purpose" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-purpose-15">purpose</a>).</p>


<p>The <dfn id="dfn-means" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">means</dfn> are the general method of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-process" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-process-33">data processing</a> through which a given
<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-purpose" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-purpose-16">purpose</a> is implemented, in a given <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-26">context</a>, considered at a relatively abstract
level and not necessarily all the way down to implementation details. Example:
<em>a person will have their preferences restored (purpose) by looking up their identifier
in a preferences store (means)</em>.</p>
</section></section>

<section class="appendix" id="high-level-threats"><div class="header-wrapper"><h2 id="threats"><bdi class="secno">B. </bdi>High-Level Threats</h2><a class="self-link" href="#threats" aria-label="Permalink for Appendix B."></a></div>

<p>User agents should attempt to defend the people using them from a variety of high-level
threats or attacker goals, described in this section.</p>
<p>These threats are an extension of the ones discussed by [<cite><a class="bibref" data-link-type="biblio" href="#bib-rfc6973" title="Privacy Considerations for Internet Protocols">RFC6973</a></cite>].</p>
<dl>
<dt><dfn id="dfn-surveillance" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">Surveillance</dfn>

</dt><dd> Surveillance is the observation or monitoring of an individual’s
communications or activities. See <a href="https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6973#section-5.1.1">RFC6973§5.1.1</a>.

</dd><dt>Data Compromise

</dt><dd> End systems that do not take adequate measures to secure data from
    unauthorized or inappropriate access. See <a href="https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6973#section-5.1.2">RFC6973§5.1.2</a>.

</dd><dt><dfn id="dfn-intrusion" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">Intrusion</dfn>

</dt><dd> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-intrusion" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-intrusion-1">Intrusion</a> consists of invasive acts that disturb or interrupt one’s life or
    activities. See <a href="https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6973#section-5.1.3">RFC6973§5.1.3</a>.

</dd><dt>Misattribution

</dt><dd> Misattribution occurs when data or communications related to one individual
    are attributed to another. See <a href="https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6973#section-5.1.4">RFC6973§5.1.4</a>.

</dd><dt><dfn id="dfn-correlation" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">Correlation</dfn>

</dt><dd> Correlation is the combination of various pieces of information related to an
    individual or that obtain that characteristic when combined. See
    <a href="https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6973#section-5.2.1">RFC6973§5.2.1</a>.

</dd><dt>Profiling</dt>

<dd>The inference, evaluation, or prediction of an individual's attributes, interests, or
behaviours.</dd>

<dt><dfn id="dfn-identification" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">Identification</dfn>

</dt><dd>Identification is the linking of information to a particular individual, even if the information
isn't linked to that individual's real-world identity (e.g. their legal name, address, government ID
number, etc.). Identifying someone allows a system to treat them differently from others, which can
be <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-inappropriately" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-inappropriately-9">inappropriate</a> depending on the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-27">context</a>. See
<a href="https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6973#section-5.2.2">RFC6973§5.2.2</a>.

</dd><dt><dfn id="dfn-secondary-use" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">Secondary Use</dfn>

</dt><dd> Secondary use is the use of collected information about an individual without
    the individual’s consent for a purpose different from that for which the
    information was collected. See <a href="https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6973#section-5.2.3">RFC6973§5.2.3</a>.

</dd><dt><dfn id="dfn-disclosure" tabindex="0" aria-haspopup="dialog" data-dfn-type="dfn">Disclosure</dfn>

</dt><dd>Disclosure is the revelation of information about an individual that affects
    the way others judge the individual. See <a href="https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6973#section-5.2.4">RFC6973§5.2.4</a>.

</dd><dt>Exclusion

</dt><dd>Exclusion is the failure to allow individuals to know about the data that
    others have about them and to participate in its handling and use. See
    <a href="https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6973#section-5.2.5">RFC6973§5.2.5</a>.

</dd></dl>

<p>These threats combine into the particular concrete threats we want web
specifications to defend against, described in the sections that follow.</p>
</section>

<section class="appendix" id="bp-summary"><div class="header-wrapper"><h2 id="c-best-practices-summary"><bdi class="secno">C. </bdi>Principles Summary</h2><a class="self-link" href="#bp-summary" aria-label="Permalink for Appendix C."></a></div><ul><li><a class="marker self-link" href="#principle-identity-per-context"><bdi lang="en">Principle</bdi></a>: <span class="practicelab">A <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-33">user agent</a> should help
its user present the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-17">identity</a> they want in each <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-context" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-context-28">context</a> they find themself
in.</span></li><li><a class="marker self-link" href="#principle-prevent-cross-partition-recognition"><bdi lang="en">Principle</bdi></a>: <span class="practicelab"><a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-34">User agents</a>
should ensure that, if a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-109">person</a> visits two or more web pages from different <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-partition" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-partition-6">partitions</a>, that
the pages cannot quickly determine that the visits probably came from the same person, for any
significant or involuntary fraction of the people who use the web, unless the person explicitly
expresses the same <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-identity" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-identity-18">identity</a> to the visits, or preventing this correlation would break a
technical feature that is fundamental to the Web.</span></li><li><a class="marker self-link" href="#principle-collective-privacy"><bdi lang="en">Principle</bdi></a>: <span class="practicelab">
    Groups and various forms of institutions should best protect and support autonomy by making
    decisions collectively rather than individually to either prevent or enable data
    sharing, and to set defaults for data processing rules.
  </span></li><li><a class="marker self-link" href="#principle-protect-unwanted-information"><bdi lang="en">Principle</bdi></a>: <span class="practicelab">
    <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-user-agent" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-user-agent-35">User agents</a> and other <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-actors" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-actors-14">actors</a> should take
    steps to ensure that their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-110">user</a> is not exposed to unwanted information. Technical standards
    must consider the delivery of unwanted information as part of their architecture and must
    mitigate it accordingly.
  </span></li><li><a class="marker self-link" href="#principle-consent-user-preference"><bdi lang="en">Principle</bdi></a>: <span class="practicelab">
    When any <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-actors" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-actors-15">actor</a> obtains <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-opt-in" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-opt-in-15">consent</a> for processing from a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-111">person</a>, the
    actor should design the consent request so as to learn the person's true
    intent to consent or not, and not to maximize the processing consented to.
  </span></li><li><a class="marker self-link" href="#principle-minimize-consent-requests"><bdi lang="en">Principle</bdi></a>: <span class="practicelab">
    An <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-actors" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-actors-16">actor</a> should avoid interrupting a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#dfn-individual" class="internalDFN" id="ref-for-dfn-individual-112">person</a>'s use of a site for
    consent requests when an alternative is available.
  </span></li><li><a class="marker self-link" href="#principle-consent-withdraw"><bdi lang="en">Principle</bdi></a>: <span class="practicelab">
    It should be as easy for a user to check what consent they have given,
    to withdraw consent, or to opt out or object,
    as to give consent.
  </span></li></ul></section>
